title: Welcome to the Ethiopian Biometric Society
text:
Ethiopian Biometry Society (EBS)
The Ethiopian Region, founded in 1999, is an active Region of IBS. In addition to this, they are a member of the Sub-Sahara African Network, or SUSAN, which is a network of national biometric groups of the Sub-Saharan African countries that promote the advancement of life sciences through the development, application, and dissemination of effective mathematical and statistical methods.
Click to learn more


This includes applications in agriculture, medical and health research, infectious diseases, environment and ecology, climate, and other applied sciences such as the areas of statistical genetics and bioinformatics.

Workshop Overview


The 19th Biennial Conference of the Sub-Saharan Network (SUSAN) of the International Biometrics Society (IBS) Pre-Workshops at the SUSAN Conference Dates: 3–4 September 2025 Location: Elilly International Hotel, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia


Workshop 1: Data Wrangling and Data Visualizations in Health Data Science with R

Instructors: Prof. Temesgen Zewotir, Prof. Henry Mwambi, Prof. Knowledge Chinhamu, Prof. Retius Chifurira, Prof. Faustin Habyarimana, Dr. Zelalem Getahun, Dr. Jesca Batidzirai, Dr. Mohanad Mohammed.
Description: This one-day workshop provides intensive training on data wrangling and data visualization techniques in health data science using R.
Date: 3 September 2025
Location: Elilly International Hotel, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
Learn more about Workshop 1


Workshop 2: Linear Mixed Model Analysis of Correlated Data

Instructors: Professor Alison Kelly and and Professor Clayton Forknall from the University of Queensland, Australia.
Description: This two-day workshop focuses on linear mixed models for the analysis of correlated health data, including theory and practical applications.
Dates: 3–4 September 2025
Location: Elilly International Hotel, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
Learn more about Workshop 2


Workshop 3: Data Analysis, Modeling, Reporting, Output Production, and Online Content Development Using R

Instructors: Dr. Rudradev Sengupta (rudradev.sengupta@one2treat.com) and Prof. Dr. Ziv Shkedy (ziv.shkedy@uhasselt.be).
Description: This one-day workshop covers data analysis, modeling, report generation, and online content development using R.
Date: 4 September 2025
Location: Elilly International Hotel, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
Learn more about Workshop 3


Workshop 4: Geospatial Mapping with R for Health Data

Instructors: Prof. Temesgen Zewotir, Prof. Henry Mwambi, Prof. Knowledge Chinhamu, Prof. Retius Chifurira, Prof. Faustin Habyarimana, Dr. Zelalem Getahun, Dr. Jesca Batidzirai, Dr. Mohanad Mohammed.
Description: This one-day workshop introduces participants to geospatial mapping techniques for health data science using R.
Date: 4 September 2025
Location: Elilly International Hotel, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
Learn more about Workshop 4


Workshop 5: Modeling Longitudinal Data with Time-Dependent Covariates

Instructors: Professor Jeffrey Wilson, Professor of Statistics and Biostatistics, Associate Dean for Research and Associate Dean for Inclusive Excellence, W. P. Carey School of Business, Arizona State University, USA.
Professor Ding-Geng Chen, Elected Member of the Academy of Science of South Africa (MASSAf) and Elected Fellow of the American Statistical Association South Africa SARChI Chair in Biostatistics and Extraordinary Professor, University of Pretoria, South Africa, Executive Director and Professor in Biostatistics, College of Health Solutions, Arizona State University, USA.
Description: This half-day workshop explores the handling of time-varying covariates in statistical modeling, essential for longitudinal health studies.
Date: 3 September 2025 (Afternoon).
Location: Elilly International Hotel, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
Learn more about Workshop 5


Workshop 6: Small Area Estimation using Official Statistics for Health Indicators

Instructors: Seyifemickael Amare Yilema and Professor Ding-Geng Chen
Description: This half-day workshop introduces Small Area Estimation (SAE) techniques for producing reliable health indicators in unplanned domains using survey and census data. The course will also cover spatial and multivariate model extensions, and introduce the Generalized SAE (GSAE) approach.
Dates: 4 September 2025 (Morning). Location: Elilly International Hotel, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
Learn more about Workshop 6

Workshop 7: Computationally Efficient Bayesian Inference for Complex Biomedical Follow-Up Data: A Semiparametric Joint Modeling with INLA

Instructors: Dr. Melkamu Molla Ferede and Professor Ding-Geng Chen
Description: This half-day workshop offers hands-on training on semiparametric joint modeling using INLA in R. Participants will explore methods for modeling competing risks survival and skewed longitudinal data, and gain experience in fast, Bayesian inference for biomedical studies.
Date: 4 September 2025 (Afternoon).
Location: Elilly International Hotel, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia
Learn more about Workshop 7

text:
Workshop 3 (WS3): Data Analysis, Modeling, Reporting, Output Production and Online Content Development Using R


One-Day Training Course Outline


Course Description

A modern data analysis requires not only analyzing a dataset but also communicating the data analysis and modeling results, and producing high-quality outputs that can be shared with clients, students, colleagues, etc. In many cases, the data analyst is also asked to develop software to conduct the data analysis and provide training materials for the developed software.
The course covers examples of data analysis and the methods/approaches to produce different types of outputs related to data analysis that can be shared online and offline with data providers, colleagues, and students.
For all the examples covered in the course, we use the R software.

Course Prerequisites


Basic familiarity with R, RStudio, and R Markdown
Basic knowledge of ggplot2
Participants are encouraged to follow Workshop 1 on 03/09/25


For Whom?

The course was developed for the following groups:

Professional data scientists and (bio)statisticians, and PhD students who need to conduct analysis as part of a research project or data analysis task
Academic staff who need to teach a course, either as part of a curriculum or as a short training course
BSc and MSc students in data science, (bio)statistics, bioinformatics, and epidemiology


Course Outline

The course consists of two parts:

Morning Sessions (3–3.5 hours):
Covering basic data analysis using R (both inference and modeling) and how to produce outputs that can be uploaded online (or used offline) based on the examples covered.
Afternoon Sessions (3–3.5 hours):
Shifting gears to illustrate how the methods/approaches from the morning can be used to produce online materials for a website, online (and offline) books, publications, etc.


Course Materials

We follow an “open source” approach, and all course materials will be available for free online.
This includes: - Slides for the course - HTML files with the outputs produced for the examples - R Markdown files with the code for all examples covered in the course

Teachers


Dr. Rudradev Sengupta (rudradev.sengupta@one2treat.com)

Workshop 1 (WS1): Data Wrangling and Data Visualizations in Health Data Science with R


One- Day Training Course Outline


Course Description

This hands-on course provides a comprehensive introduction to data manipulation and visualization using R, specifically tailored for health data science. Participants will learn essential skills for cleaning, transforming, and visualizing healthcare datasets including patient records, clinical trials, and public health data. Through practical exercises, attendees will gain proficiency in using R’s Tidyverse ecosystem to derive insights from complex health data.

Course Prerequisites


Basic familiarity with R syntax and RStudio interface
Understanding of fundamental data types (vectors, data frames)


Course Outcomes


Clean and prepare messy health datasets for analysis
Perform advanced data transformations using dplyr and tidyr
Create publication-quality visualizations with ggplot2
Handle temporal health data and categorical variables effectively


Course Objectives


Master RStudio for health data analysis workflows
Develop strategies for handling missing values in medical datasets
Implement efficient data merging/joining techniques for multi-source health data
Create diagnostic visualizations for health metrics (blood pressure, age distributions, etc.)
Transform data between wide/long formats for different analytical needs
Generate time-series visualizations for patient monitoring and trend analysis

Strengthening (Bio)Statistics and Data Science Education and Research Resources in Sub-Saharan Africa


Join us for an engaging session focused on capacity building and research enhancement in biostatistics and data science at universities across sub-Saharan Africa. Over the years, significant investments have been made in higher education, training, and research. Traditionally, these partnerships have followed a North-South donor-recipient model. However, recent developments highlight the importance of integrating robust South-South collaborations to create more effective educational partnerships.


This session will showcase several ongoing initiatives supported by various organizations, emphasizing mutual North-South-South partnerships that have emerged in recent years. The presentations will cover four key topics that have fostered capacity building in biostatistics and data science across the region.


Session Overview


The session will feature four 20-minute presentations:



Prof. Tobias Chirwa (University of the Witwatersrand, South Africa) will provide an overview of the SSACAB consortium, which aims to strengthen biostatistics education in sub-Saharan Africa.


Prof. Ann Mwangi (Moi University, Kenya) will discuss the long-term Moi-Brown collaboration focused on HIV biostatistics research training and capacity development activities.


Prof. Ziv Shkedy (Hasselt University, Belgium) will present an open-source E-learning platform, eR-Biostat, designed to support researchers, teachers, and students in statistics and data science.


Prof. Tarylee Reddy (SA-MRC, South Africa) will give an overview of the International Biometric Society’s (IBS) mentoring program and its activities in sub-Saharan Africa.



These initiatives exemplify diverse approaches to enhancing education and research in biostatistics and data science in sub-Saharan Africa. Each relies on strong collaborative networks and aims to produce sustainable deliverables that will remain accessible long after initial funding concludes.


Session Details



Chair: Prof. Samuel Manda (University of Pretoria, South Africa)


Discussant: Prof. Misrak Gezmu (NIH, USA)


Discussion: A 30-minute discussion will follow, focusing on developing sustainable education and research pathways in the region.



All presenters, the chair, and the discussant are actively involved in long-term projects that promote education and research in (bio)statistics and data science within sub-Saharan Africa.


Don’t miss this opportunity to learn about impactful initiatives and contribute to the discussion on strengthening our educational resources!

Welcome Note by the Chair of IBS Ethiopian Region


19th Biennial SUSAN Conference Date: September 3, 2025 Location: Addis Ababa, Ethiopia


Honorable guests, esteemed colleagues, and distinguished members of the International Biometrics Society,


It is an immense privilege to welcome you all to the 19th Biennial Conference of the Sub-Saharan Network (SUSAN) of the IBS. This gathering stands as a testament to our shared commitment to advancing biometrics and data science for the betterment of health and agriculture across the developing world.


As we convene here in Addis Ababa, we embark on a journey of knowledge exchange, collaboration, and innovation. The Ethiopian Biometric Society, alongside our partners at IBS, is deeply honored to host this distinguished event, bringing together some of the brightest minds in biostatistics, bioinformatics, artificial intelligence, and data science.


Our conference theme—“Biometrics and data science to enhance health and agriculture in the developing world”—reminds us of our duty to harness the power of data and analytics in solving real-world challenges. In an era marked by rapid technological evolution, the ability to analyze, predict, and optimize solutions has never been more critical. From addressing disease burden estimation to pioneering machine learning applications in agriculture, the insights shared over the next few days will shape the future of biometrics in vital sectors.


We extend our sincere gratitude to all researchers, academicians, practitioners, and students who have joined us for this occasion. The diversity of perspectives and expertise in this room serves as the driving force of innovation. As we move forward, let us remain committed to fostering ethical research, embracing collaboration, and ensuring that our work translates into tangible progress for communities in need.


Let this conference be a catalyst for change. Let it inspire groundbreaking discoveries, strengthen professional networks, and reinforce our shared vision for a data-driven future that uplifts societies across Africa and beyond.


Together, we shape tomorrow. Together, we build a legacy.


Welcome to IBS SUSAN 2025!

Plan your tour to Addia Ababa


General Information About Addis Ababa and Visa Information


Traveling to Addis Ababa for the First Time?

Travel experts consider Addis Ababa a vibrant and important destination in Africa. It is a city rich in history, culture, and innovation, home to world-class museums like the National Museum of Ethiopia, the African Union headquarters, and bustling traditional markets like Merkato. Visitors to Addis Ababa will experience its unique blend of tradition and modernity, diverse cuisine, and warm hospitality.


Steps for Visa Application to Ethiopia


Step 1: Conference Registration

Start by registering for the conference and retain a copy of your payment confirmation and registration. When registering, make sure to indicate if you require a visa invitation letter, which will be provided by the conference organizers.
👉 go to registration Page

Step 2: Hotel Accommodations

Book your hotel through the conference rooming block at designated hotels in Addis Ababa. This will offer you the best rates and serve as additional proof of your legitimate travel purpose.
👉 hotel information

Step 3: Flight Arrangements

Book your flight early, ideally after submitting your visa application.

Step 4: Ethiopian Visa Application

Most travelers will need a visa to enter Ethiopia.
You can apply:

Online through the official E-Visa Portal: https://www.evisa.gov.et/
Or through the nearest Ethiopian Embassy or Consulate in your country.

Typically, you will apply for a Conference Visa (CV) or a Tourist Visa (TV) depending on your planned activities. Processing times may vary, so apply well in advance.


Important Information About Ethiopian Visa Applications


What is an Ethiopian Visa?

A visa is an official authorization placed in your passport that allows you to enter Ethiopia. Travelers from many countries can now apply for an E-Visa online.

Visa-Free and Visa-on-Arrival

Citizens of some nations and diplomatic passport holders may be exempt from requiring a visa. Otherwise, most international travelers must obtain a visa either online or prior to arrival.

Electronic Visa (E-Visa)

Ethiopia’s E-Visa is available to citizens of many countries and is strongly recommended for ease of travel.
👉 Apply through the official Ethiopian E-Visa Portal

Types of Visas


Conference Visa (CV): For those attending the conference specifically.
Tourist Visa (TV): If you also plan sightseeing in Ethiopia after the conference.



Required Documents for Visa Application

Be prepared to provide:

A letter of invitation from the conference organizers (if requested).
Proof of registration and payment for the conference.
Hotel booking confirmation.
Flight reservation (matching the name in your passport).


Important:

Make sure that the name on your visa application exactly matches the name on your passport, as discrepancies can cause delays.


Additional Notes


Ethiopian immigration officers reserve the right to permit or deny entry upon arrival.
Upon arrival, you will go through Customs and Immigration at Bole International Airport in Addis Ababa.
Always carry a printed copy of your visa approval and invitation letter when traveling.
The conference organizers cannot intervene in individual visa applications or expedite processing.



For More Information

👉 Visit the official Ethiopian E-Visa website: Ethiopian eVisa Official Website

Workshop 2 (WS2): Linear Mixed Model Analysis of Correlated Data


Presented by: Prof. Alison Kelly and Professor Clayton Forknall  The University of Queensland, Australia


Two- Day Training Course Outline


Course Description


Introduction to Linear Mixed Models: Understand the framework and its advantages for analyzing data from designed experiments.
Progressive Development: Start with simple linear models and gradually incorporate more complex fixed and random effects using Residual Maximum Likelihood (REML) estimation.
Complex Variance Structures: Learn how to extend models to fit complex variance structures that account for dependencies over time and space.
Practical Sessions: Engage in hands-on activities using the R statistical software package, allowing participants to analyze their own research data. Who Should Attend?

This workshop is ideal for researchers and practitioners in biological sciences who are looking to enhance their data analysis skills using linear mixed models. Whether you are new to the topic or seeking to deepen your understanding, this workshop will provide valuable insights and practical experience.

Don’t miss this opportunity to learn from experts and improve your data analysis capabilities!

title: Health Data Science: Data Visualizations and Wrangling with R
text:
Presented by: UKZN Data Science Group
Instructors:
- Prof. Temesgen Zewotir
- Prof. Henry Mwambi
- Prof. Retius Chifurira
- Prof. Faustin Habyarimana
- Dr. Zelalem Getahun
- Dr. Jesca Batidzirai
- Dr. Mohanad Mohammed


This intensive short course introduces essential skills in health data science, focusing on data wrangling and visualization using R. Participants will learn to clean, manipulate, and prepare health data for analysis, create compelling visualizations, and effectively communicate findings. Through hands-on exercises, students will gain practical experience with popular R packages such as dplyr and ggplot2, enabling them to transform complex datasets into clear insights. This course is ideal for beginners and healthcare professionals looking to enhance their data skills.




Understand the Role of Data Analysis: Grasp how data analysis informs healthcare decisions and policies.
Foundational R Programming Skills: Develop skills in R and become familiar with RStudio as a development environment.
Data Import and Export: Learn efficient methods for importing and exporting data in various formats.
Data Manipulation with dplyr and tidyr: Clean and manipulate health data by filtering, summarizing, and reshaping datasets.
Handling Missing Data: Identify missing values and apply strategies for imputation to maintain data integrity.
Creating Visualizations with ggplot2: Produce visualizations such as bar charts, scatter plots, and heatmaps to effectively communicate insights.
Interpreting and Communicating Results: Convey findings clearly to diverse audiences, emphasizing context and implications.
Case Studies in Health Data: Apply learned techniques to real-world health data sets in public health and clinical practice.
Ethics in Data Presentation: Understand the ethical implications, including privacy, bias, and responsible data use.
Continuous Learning: Foster a mindset of continuous improvement, encouraging collaboration and providing resources for further study.





Introduction to R for Health Data Science

Setting up R and RStudio
Basic R syntax and data structures (vectors, data frames, lists)

Data Import and Export

Importing data from various sources (CSV, Excel, databases)
Exporting cleaned data for analysis or reporting

Data Wrangling Techniques

Introduction to the tidyverse package
Using dplyr for data manipulation (filtering, selecting, arranging, summarizing)
Reshaping data with tidyr (pivoting, gathering, spreading)

Handling Missing Data

Identifying and understanding missing data
Strategies for imputation and data cleaning

Data Visualization Principles

Importance of visualization in health data science
Choosing the right type of visualization for different data types

Creating Visualizations with ggplot2

Introduction to ggplot2 syntax and structure
Creating basic plots: bar charts, histograms, scatter plots
Customizing visualizations (colors, labels, themes)

Advanced Visualization Techniques

Faceting and combining multiple plots
Visualizing time series data
Heatmaps and correlation plots

Interpreting and Communicating Results

Best practices for presenting visualizations
Writing effective captions and annotations
Ethical considerations in data presentation

Case Studies and Applications

Analyzing real-world health datasets (e.g., public health data, clinical trials)
Group projects on specific health issues

Resources for Further Learning


Recommended books, online courses, and communities
Exploring additional R packages for health data analysis

Addis Ababa, Ethiopia’s vibrant capital, seamlessly blends ancient traditions with modern innovation. As the diplomatic heart of Africa, it boasts historical treasures like the National Museum of Ethiopia, the Holy Trinity Cathedral, etc. Visitors can immerse themselves in a rich tapestry of culture, cuisine, and warm hospitality. Whether exploring centuries-old churches or contemporary art galleries, Addis Ababa offers unforgettable experiences at every turn.


Tours and Excursions


Below are some recommended tour and excursion options available through third-party providers. Please click on the links for more details and registration instructions. 


National Museum of Ethiopia — Home to the famous fossil “Lucy” and a remarkable collection of Ethiopia’s archaeological and historical treasures.


Holy Trinity Cathedral — One of Ethiopia’s most important religious sites, known for its stunning stained-glass windows and imperial history.


Unity Park at the National Palace — A beautifully restored historic site showcasing Ethiopia’s cultural, natural, and political heritage.


Ethnological Museum — Located within Haile Selassie’s former palace, this museum offers fascinating insights into Ethiopia’s diverse cultures.


Red Terror Martyrs’ Memorial Museum — A moving memorial documenting Ethiopia’s modern political history.


Victory Memorial Museum (Adwa Victory Memorial Museum) — A new and impressive museum honoring Ethiopia’s victory at the Battle of Adwa, showcasing Ethiopia’s proud history and heritage.


Entoto Park — A massive eco-park offering adventure sports, restaurants, cultural centers, and breathtaking scenery atop Mount Entoto.



We encourage visitors to plan ahead — spaces on popular tours may be limited. Immerse yourself in the beauty, resilience, and energy of Addis Ababa during your stay!

Workshop 5 (WS5): Modeling Longitudinal Data with Time-Dependent Covariates


Presented by: Dr. Jeffrey R. Wilson and Dr. Ding-Geng (Din) Chen  Arizona State University, USA


Half-Day Training Course Outline


Course Description


This applied workshop introduces practical strategies for modeling longitudinal data with time-dependent covariates, using real-world examples from health, behavioral, and policy research.
Time-dependent covariates—such as changing medication use, behavioral exposures, or symptom scores—pose unique challenges in longitudinal studies.
Participants will learn how to recognize and model these variables using marginal models (e.g., GEE), mixed-effects models, and joint modeling frameworks.
Through a combination of lecture and live coding demonstrations, the workshop will emphasize modeling approaches that address feedback, covariate timing, and dynamic exposure-outcome relationships.
Hands-on examples will guide attendees through the implementation of these models in both SAS and R, with optional demonstrations using Stan for Bayesian extensions.
By the end of the workshop, participants will be equipped to build, estimate, and interpret longitudinal models that incorporate time-dependent covariates in both continuous and binary outcome contexts.


Prerequisites


A course in regression

Familiarity with longitudinal data structure and basic statistical inference

Prior experience using R or SAS is helpful but not required


Learning Objectives

By the end of the workshop, participants will be able to:

Differentiate between time-independent and time-dependent covariates in longitudinal data.

Understand the implications of using time-dependent covariates in marginal, conditional, and joint models.

Identify situations involving feedback, endogeneity, and measurement timing.

Implement marginal models using Generalized Estimating Equations (GEE) and linear mixed-effects models.

Fit models with time-dependent covariates using SAS and R.

Interpret model results for time-varying effects and provide insight into dynamic change processes.


Textbook (Recommended)

Wilson, J., Vazquez, E. and Chen, D. G. (2020). Marginal Models in Analysis of Correlated Binary Data with Time-Dependent Covariates. Springer.
(https://www.springer.com/gp/book/9783030489038)

Laptop Requirement

Yes. Participants should bring a laptop with:
- R and RStudio pre-installed
- SAS (if available)
Workshop materials and code examples will be provided in advance.

About the Instructors

Dr. Jeffrey R. Wilson
Professor of Statistics and Biostatistics, Arizona State University
Dr. Wilson’s research spans correlated binary models, longitudinal data analysis, and public health analytics. He has authored over 100 peer-reviewed papers in journals such as Statistics in Medicine and Management Science and consults extensively in health care, law, and social policy.
Dr. Ding-Geng (Din) Chen
Executive Director and Professor of Biostatistics, College of Health Solutions, Arizona State University
Extraordinary Professor of Statistics, University of Pretoria, South Africa
Dr. Chen is a global leader in biostatistics and statistical methodology with over 200 peer-reviewed publications and 42 co-authored or co-edited books in areas including data science, meta-analysis, causal inference, and longitudinal modeling. He currently holds appointments in the U.S. and South Africa and is an elected member of the Academy of Science of South Africa and an elected fellow of the American Statistical Association.

Don’t miss this opportunity to learn from experts and improve your data analysis capabilities!

Workshop 6 (WS6): Small Area Estimation using Official Statistics for Health Indicators


Presented by: Seyifemickael Amare Yilema and Professor Ding-Geng Chen  University of Pretoria, South Africa & Arizona State University, USA


Half-Day Training Course Outline


Course Description


This course offers a basic area-level Small Area Estimation (SAE), which is used to provide reliable estimates by combining survey and census datasets for unplanned domains (local level administrations) when the sample sizes are small.
One of the major challenges for low- and middle-income countries is the lack of data at the local administrative level in demographic and health survey (DHS) datasets. Therefore, this course will discuss how to handle this problem with SAE.
The course starts from the fundamental principles of SAE and progresses to its advanced model extensions, including spatial, spatiotemporal, bivariate, and multivariate models.
Another key component of the course is to explore the Generalized SAE (GSAE) approach, which builds upon the generalized direct survey estimates (GDESvy), incorporating the survey independent variables.
Participants will learn the basic concepts of SAE, and its statistical model extensions in the Fay-Herriot model framework.


Prerequisites


Participants will have a basic concept of:

Sampling techniques

Spatial and spatio-temporal models

Bivariate and multivariate models



Learning Objectives

By the end of the workshop, participants will be able to:

Briefly understand the basic concepts and principle of SAE.

Learn about the extension models of SAE, including spatial, and spatiotemporal bivariate and multivariate models and examine how these extended models improved the SAE approach.

Present the recently introduced concepts of GSAE and understand how incorporating independent survey variables can improve the results.

Present how the generalized models, i.e., GSAE and GDESvy, improved the performance of the corresponding SAE and DESvy.


About the Instructors

Seyifemickael Amare Yilema
Post-doctoral Fellow in Biostatistics, Department of Statistics, University of Pretoria, Pretoria, South Africa

Workshop 7 (WS7): Computationally Efficient Bayesian Inference for Complex Biomedical Follow-Up Data: A Semiparametric Joint Modeling with INLA


Presented by: Dr. Melkamu Molla Ferede and Professor Ding-Geng (Din) Chen University of Gondar, University of Pretoria, and Arizona State University


Half-Day Training Workshop


Course Description


This half-day workshop provides a comprehensive introduction to semiparametric joint modeling of competing risks survival and skewed longitudinal data using the Integrated Nested Laplace Approximation (INLA) approach in R.
The course is designed to offer computationally efficient Bayesian inference for complex biomedical follow-up data, where traditional MCMC techniques may be limited by high dimensionality, large dataset, or computational cost.
Participants will learn to flexibly model nonlinear longitudinal trajectories, accommodate skewed distributions and competing risks in survival processes, and link these components within a joint modeling framework—incorporating smoothing splines, flexible distributions, and various association structures.


Prerequisites


Prior knowledge of survival analysis and longitudinal data analysis

Basic understanding of Bayesian inference

Basic experience with R and RStudio

Laptop with pre-installed software: R, RStudio, INLA


Learning Objectives


Understand the basic concept of joint modelling of longitudinal and time-to-event data

Model nonlinear (skewed) longitudinal outcomes using semiparametric mixed-effects models with flexible distributional assumptions

Model survival data with competing risks failure times with flexible hazard shapes

Employ various association structures in joint modeling formulations

Approximate Bayesian inference using the INLA approach, INLAjoint in R

Evaluate the computational efficiency and estimation performance of INLA and MCMC


Software Requirements

Participants are requested to bring a laptop with the following pre-installed software:
- Latest version of R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
- RStudio: https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/
- R-INLA: https://www.r-inla.org/download-install
(Note: Practical sample data and scripts will be shared before the session)

About the Instructors

Dr. Melkamu Molla Ferede
Postdoctoral Fellow in Biostatistics, University of Pretoria, South Africa
Assistant Professor of Statistics, University of Gondar, Ethiopia
Professor Ding-Geng (Din) Chen
